metadata.sermon_start_end: We are allowed in this text to peek a little ways into the mystery of evil and to glimpse its formula for getting things done. We catch a little view of the strategy of Satan. It would help us to understand the danger of playing with evil [...] The tide may bear us far, but we may well hope to see our Pilot face to face. The storm clouds may rise, the sun will still shine on our pathway.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon centers on Luke 22:31-32, but it frequently drifts into general biblical concepts (the 'strategy of Satan') and other texts (Matthew, Ephesians, Revelation). It fails to isolate what is unique to this specific passage that cannot be found elsewhere.
quotes: In our text, the Lord is saying the same thing to Simon Peter...
You remember our Lord's parable about the wheat and the tares reported to us in Matthew 13:24-30.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus exclusively on the unique dynamic of the 'sifting' and the 'prayer of Jesus' in Luke 22, rather than treating it as a general example of spiritual warfare found in Ephesians.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is minimal technical exegesis. The preacher notes the change from 'Peter' to 'Simon', which is a valid exegetical observation, but there is no evidence of Greek/Hebrew study or historical-critical depth regarding the Upper Room context.
quotes: 'Simon, Simon,' he calls Peter by his old name. It is as if Jesus is calling Peter back to his poorest, lowest self.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Investigate the plural 'you' (Satan asked for *you all*) versus the singular 'I prayed for *thee*' to show the specific theological weight of Peter’s representative role.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding the political climate (Jimmy Carter's election) and the psychology of church attendance. However, it often veers into general moralizing about 'trying to do right.'
quotes: We have elected a new president this week... he is a Southerner and white.
Miss church one Sunday and you feel less guilty, until it is easy to miss and hard to go.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the 'sifting' more specifically to the modern 'zeitgeist'—how does the modern world specifically 'sift' the believer's faith beyond just missing church?

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a somewhat linear path: anecdote, then text, then contemporary application. The 'interweaving' is loose; the hearer is not consistently 'expounded' by the text itself.
quotes: In our recent election, you can be sure that the strategists for both sides devised a plan...
Then looking at the leader of the band, Jesus lifts the veil...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid long introductory anecdotes about elections; start within the text and let the application emerge directly from the exegetical tension.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon strongly emphasizes 'misery' (the cunning of Satan) and 'redemption' (Jesus' prayer). It captures the human subject's struggle well, though 'gratitude' is presented more as a future hope than a present ethical reality.
quotes: I am always overborne and shattered within when I think of how the good Lord... takes our poor, clumsy efforts.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Develop the 'gratitude' section (the 'when you have turned back, strengthen your brothers' part of the text) as the concrete ethical response.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon acknowledges the possibility of 'turning back' and the reality of being 'lost in time,' but the 'eternal loss' is softened by a very optimistic ending. The seriousness is present but lacks the 'sharpness' Dekker demands.
quotes: If you are not careful, the devil will get hold of you. If you are not careful, you will turn back.
A person can be lost in time and in eternity.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the gravity of Peter's potential fall more starkly to highlight the 'narrow way' versus the 'broad way' of betrayal.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon correctly identifies that salvation is 'outside' the believer (in Jesus' prayer), not in the believer's own strength. It maintains the 'two natures' by showing Jesus as the one who appeals to a higher court.
quotes: Jesus right here throws in heaven's mighty answer to hell's mighty strength.
Man has no life in himself, it is Christ who is his life.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure that Christ is not just a 'helper' in a fight, but the one in whom the victory is already substantively complete.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 16.5 minutes (1650 words), the sermon fails Dekker's 20-minute minimum requirement. It lacks the 'breadth' required for true 'depth.'
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section (Thesis 2) to provide the necessary theological weight to reach the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon fails the formal requirement of length and lacks rigorous linguistic exegesis. It relies heavily on external anecdotes (the 1976 election) and general biblical themes (spiritual armor) rather than the radical specificity of the Luke 22 passage. However, it successfully addresses the human subject (misery/redemption) and maintains a clear Christological focus.
strengths: Strong psychological connection to the 'unworthiness' of the hearer.
Clear identification of Christ's intercession as the only source of security.
Concrete contemporary references that ground the spiritual struggle in reality.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (under 20 minutes) limits theological depth.
Lack of original language engagement or historical-critical depth.
Tendency to drift into 'general truths' about spiritual warfare rather than the specific 'sifting' of this text.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a 'speech about the gospel' that approaches being a sermon, but falls short of Dekker's ideal due to its brevity, lack of exegetical rigor, and occasional reliance on general biblical motifs over the specific text.
